trans-unit.source: Connect your Azure Mobile App to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Connect your Azure Mobile App to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to connect to an on-premises SQL Server from a App Service Mobile App using Hybrid Connections
trans-unit.target: Learn how to connect to an on-premises SQL Server from a App Service Mobile App using Hybrid Connections

trans-unit.source: Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from Mobile Apps using Hybrid Connections
trans-unit.target: Connect to an on-premises SQL Server from Mobile Apps using Hybrid Connections

trans-unit.source: When your enterprise transitions to the cloud, you might not be able to migrate all of your assets to Azure right away.
trans-unit.target: When your enterprise transitions to the cloud, you might not be able to migrate all of your assets to Azure right away.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections lets the Mobile Apps feature in Azure App Service securely connect to your on-premises assets.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections lets the Mobile Apps feature in Azure App Service securely connect to your on-premises assets.

trans-unit.source: In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure.

trans-unit.source: Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.
trans-unit.target: Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.

trans-unit.source: Hybrid Connections use Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization to secure the connections from your mobile service and the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to the hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: Hybrid Connections use Shared Access Signature (SAS) authorization to secure the connections from your mobile service and the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to the hybrid connection.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>Hybrid Connections Overview</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>Hybrid Connections Overview</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to modify a Mobile App .NET backend to use a local on-premises SQL Server database instead of the default Azure SQL Database provisioned with your service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to modify a Mobile App .NET backend to use a local on-premises SQL Server database instead of the default Azure SQL Database provisioned with your service.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires you to have the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires you to have the following:

trans-unit.source: An existing Mobile App backend Follow the quickstart tutorial to create and download a new .NET backend Mobile App from the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: An existing Mobile App backend Follow the quickstart tutorial to create and download a new .NET backend Mobile App from the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: Install SQL Server Express, enable TCP/IP, and create a SQL Server database on-premises
trans-unit.target: Install SQL Server Express, enable TCP/IP, and create a SQL Server database on-premises

trans-unit.source: Create a Hybrid Connection
trans-unit.target: Create a Hybrid Connection

trans-unit.source: You need to create a new Hybrid Connection and BizTalk service for the code portion of your Mobile App backend, which is a web app.
trans-unit.target: You need to create a new Hybrid Connection and BizTalk service for the code portion of your Mobile App backend, which is a web app.

trans-unit.source: In the [Azure Portal], browse to your Mobile App and click the web app backend button.
trans-unit.target: In the [Azure Portal], browse to your Mobile App and click the web app backend button.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Navigate to web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Navigate to web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This takes you to the web app that implements the backend code for your Mobile App, which is the name of your Mobile App followed by -code.
trans-unit.target: This takes you to the web app that implements the backend code for your Mobile App, which is the name of your Mobile App followed by -code.

trans-unit.source: Scroll down the web app's blade and click Hybrid connections.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down the web app's blade and click Hybrid connections.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hybrid connections</linkText>

trans-unit.source: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add then New hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: On the Hybrid connections blade, click Add then New hybrid connection.

trans-unit.source: On the Create hybrid connection blade, provide a Name and Host Name for your hybrid connection and set Port to 1433.
trans-unit.target: On the Create hybrid connection blade, provide a Name and Host Name for your hybrid connection and set Port to 1433.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a hybrid connection</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Biz Talk Service and enter a name for the BizTalk service and click OK twice.
trans-unit.target: Click Biz Talk Service and enter a name for the BizTalk service and click OK twice.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses mobile1.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses mobile1.

trans-unit.source: you'll need to supply a unique name for your new BizTalk Service.
trans-unit.target: you'll need to supply a unique name for your new BizTalk Service.

trans-unit.source: After the process completes, the Notifications area flashes a green SUCCESS and the Hybrid connection blade shows the new hybrid connection with the status as Not connected.
trans-unit.target: After the process completes, the Notifications area flashes a green SUCCESS and the Hybrid connection blade shows the new hybrid connection with the status as Not connected.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>One hybrid connection created</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>One hybrid connection created</linkText>

trans-unit.source: At this point, you've completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you've completed an important part of the cloud hybrid connection infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll create a corresponding on-premises piece.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll create a corresponding on-premises piece.

trans-unit.source: Install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to complete the connection
trans-unit.target: Install the on-premises Hybrid Connection Manager to complete the connection

trans-unit.source: Configure the Mobile App backend project to connect to the SQL Server database
trans-unit.target: Configure the Mobile App backend project to connect to the SQL Server database

trans-unit.source: In this step, you define a connection string for the on-premises database and modify the Mobile App backend to use this connection.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you define a connection string for the on-premises database and modify the Mobile App backend to use this connection.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, open the project that defines your Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, open the project that defines your Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to download your .NET backend project, see <link><linkText>quickstart tutorial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to download your .NET backend project, see <link><linkText>quickstart tutorial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, open the Web.config file, locate the connectionStrings section, add a new SqlClient entry like the following, which points to the on-premises SQL Server database:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, open the Web.config file, locate the connectionStrings section, add a new SqlClient entry like the following, which points to the on-premises SQL Server database:

trans-unit.source: Remember to replace <**secure_password**> in this string with the password you created for HbyridConnectionLogin.
trans-unit.target: Remember to replace <**secure_password**> in this string with the password you created for HbyridConnectionLogin.

trans-unit.source: Click Save in Visual Studio to save the Web.config file.
trans-unit.target: Click Save in Visual Studio to save the Web.config file.

trans-unit.source: This connection setting is used when running on the local computer.
trans-unit.target: This connection setting is used when running on the local computer.

trans-unit.source: When running in Azure, this setting is overriden by the connection setting defined in the portal.
trans-unit.target: When running in Azure, this setting is overriden by the connection setting defined in the portal.

trans-unit.source: Expand the Models folder and open the data model file, which ends in Context.cs.
trans-unit.target: Expand the Models folder and open the data model file, which ends in Context.cs.

trans-unit.source: Modify the DbContext instance constructor to pass the value OnPremisesDBConnection to the base DbContext constructor, similar to the following snippet:
trans-unit.target: Modify the DbContext instance constructor to pass the value OnPremisesDBConnection to the base DbContext constructor, similar to the following snippet:

trans-unit.source: The service will now use the new connection to the SQL Server database.
trans-unit.target: The service will now use the new connection to the SQL Server database.

trans-unit.source: Update Azure to use the on-premises connection string
trans-unit.target: Update Azure to use the on-premises connection string

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to add an app setting for this new connection string so that it can be used from Azure.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to add an app setting for this new connection string so that it can be used from Azure.

trans-unit.source: Back in the [Azure Portal] in the web app backend code for your Mobile App, click All settings, then Application settings.
trans-unit.target: Back in the [Azure Portal] in the web app backend code for your Mobile App, click All settings, then Application settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Web app settings blade, scroll down to Connection strings and add an new SQL Server connection string named OnPremisesDBConnection with a value like Server=OnPremisesServer,1433;Database=OnPremisesDB;User ID=HybridConnectionsLogin;Password=<**secure_password**>.
trans-unit.target: In the Web app settings blade, scroll down to Connection strings and add an new SQL Server connection string named OnPremisesDBConnection with a value like Server=OnPremisesServer,1433;Database=OnPremisesDB;User ID=HybridConnectionsLogin;Password=<**secure_password**>.

trans-unit.source: Replace <**secure_password**> with the secure password for your on-premises database.
trans-unit.target: Replace <**secure_password**> with the secure password for your on-premises database.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connection string for on-premises database</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connection string for on-premises database</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Press Save to save the hybrid connection and connection string you just created.
trans-unit.target: Press Save to save the hybrid connection and connection string you just created.

trans-unit.source: Publish and test the Mobile App backend in Azure
trans-unit.target: Publish and test the Mobile App backend in Azure

trans-unit.source: Finally, you need to publish the Mobile App backend to Azure and verify that it is using the hybrid connection to store data in the on-premises database.
trans-unit.target: Finally, you need to publish the Mobile App backend to Azure and verify that it is using the hybrid connection to store data in the on-premises database.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the project, click Publish, then in Publish Web click Microsoft Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the project, click Publish, then in Publish Web click Microsoft Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: Instead of using Visual Studio, you can also <link><linkText>use Git to publish your backend</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Instead of using Visual Studio, you can also <link><linkText>use Git to publish your backend</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with your Azure credentials and select your service from Select Existing Websites.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with your Azure credentials and select your service from Select Existing Websites.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio downloads your publish settings directly from Azure.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio downloads your publish settings directly from Azure.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click Publish.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click Publish.

trans-unit.source: After publishing completes, the service restarts and the backend start page is displayed.
trans-unit.target: After publishing completes, the service restarts and the backend start page is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your Mobile App, invoke some operations that generate database changes.
trans-unit.target: Using either the Try it now button on the start page as before or using a client app connected to your Mobile App, invoke some operations that generate database changes.

trans-unit.source: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).
trans-unit.target: When you use the Try it now button to launch the Help API pages, remember to supply your application key as the password (with a blank username).

trans-unit.source: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to your SQL Server instance, open the Object Explorer, expand the OnPremisesDB database and expand Tables.
trans-unit.target: In SQL Server Management Studio, connect to your SQL Server instance, open the Object Explorer, expand the OnPremisesDB database and expand Tables.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the hybridService1.TodoItems table and choose Select Top 1000 Rows to view the results.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the hybridService1.TodoItems table and choose Select Top 1000 Rows to view the results.

trans-unit.source: Note that changes generated in your client app are saved by your Mobile App backend to your on-premises database using the hybrid connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that changes generated in your client app are saved by your Mobile App backend to your on-premises database using the hybrid connection.

trans-unit.target: See Also

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>How to make data model changes to a .NET backend mobile service</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
